It's me Gordon, Barney from Black Mesa! Sorry for the scare, I had to put on a show for the cameras. I can't take too long or they'll get suspicious, I'm way behind on my beating quota.
Yes Barney, what is it? I'm in the middle of a critical test!
Sorry, Doc, but look who's here.
Great Scott! Gordon Freeman! I expected more warning.
Yeah, you and me both, Doc. He was about to board the Express to Nova Prospekt.
Well, Barney, what do you intend?
Alyx is around here, somewhere... She would have a better idea how to get him here.
Well, as long as he stays away from checkpoints we should be okay. 	Listen, I gotta go, Doc. We're taking enough chances as it is.
Very well. And, eh, Gordon? Good to see you!
Okay, Gordon you're gonna have to make your own way to Dr. Kleiner's lab. Oh man, that's what I was afraid of. Get in here, Gordon, before you blow my cover. Pile up some stuff to get through that window, and keep going 'til you're in the plaza. I'll meet up with you later.

Игра которая способствовала продвижению плаформы стим.Итак после всех бед что творились в прошлой части наш немногословный герой волею судьбы оказывается в Сити 17-этакий постсоветский городок в восточной Европе со всеми вытекающими (за здания и всю прочую архитектуру огромное спасибо Виктору Антонову, именно он отвечал за дизайн игры.К слову он ещё к dishonored руку приложил) где мы примыкаем к группе повстанцев ,вместе скоторыми боремся за падение тоталитарного режима воцарившегося в мире(( к слову страны восточной Европы не понаслышке знакомы с данным hardcore режимом)Несмотря на вполне солидный возраст игра даже сейчас (2020) ощущается очень хорошо , графика не режет глаза да и не перенапрегает всё теже глаза)В общем если в мире ещё остался человек не игравший в этот шедевр и этот человек именно ты....ты знаешь что делать.

The sound design is amazing love It.

+ The gun-play is satisfying and has held up
+ Much more involving story in comparison to the first game
+ No frame drops, crashes, or other technical issues

- Certain objectives and paths are very obscured from sight
- Vehicle mechanics are bad, even by 2004 standards
- Ladders work better than the first game, but are still annoying to use
- Ally A.I. is HORRENDOUS! 

My biggest issue, and why I wouldn't recommend the game, are the mechanics. They don't feel like they've been improved from the first game and get in the way of what good the game has to offer, to the point that they ruin the experience. The ally A.I. being by far the biggest problem. Other FPS games from the time had better ally A.I. that helped and listened to in-game commands; Socom U.S. Navy Seals being a prime example. Having to constantly restart objectives because ally A.I. are running into the open to die, blocking you in rooms with no way out, blocking you from retreating to cover and dying, or leaving you helpless by not giving available health and ammo drops, completely negate any positives and made me more relieved than excited when I finished the game.

TLDR:  A decent, classic shooter that wasn't as much fun as I wanted it to be.

I didn't play Half-Life 2 on release so doing so sixteen years later means I didn't have the same nostalgia factor I did for the first game, and I'm sure that's part of my issue with it.

HL2 takes place years after the events of the first game. The player is back as Gordon Freeman, awoken from a long stasis. You discover the creatures from the dimension you ripped into at Black Mesa have now taken over the world and a blended human-alien government called the Combine (appropriately) is in charge. Of course, you're there to wreck all that.

HL2 uses the standard WASD/mouse control scheme, with left mouse to fire your equipped weapons and right mouse for secondary use. You can interact with certain objects and personnel, much like in the first game. You'll get companions at various points, some of whom you can control and order to move with you or fall back.

One new feature was the inclusion of the gravity gun, a special weapon which will let you pick up mobile objects and hurl them at great force, and that's not all. Grenades can be grabbed from midair and hurled back at your foe, or sawblades shot at zombies (with satisfying results). You can pick up and throw mines and explosive barrels at enemies. You can use it to stack boxes to climb to certain places. If you blast an enemy soldier and he falls out of reach, you can sometimes pull his weapon to yourself for a reload. There's a lot of things you can do with it and overall, I found it to be one of the best components to the game.

I found the combat flowed a little better than the first game, though dealing with the wasp-like gunships was irritating. I did like that compared to the first game, it felt like there were less puzzles to solve--you know, having to make running leaps onto a platform the size of a paperback book to advance. The ones here felt organic and (in general) didn't slow things down too much. Some of the fights allowed experimentation with different strategies, like ones where you have to place turrets to help fend off incoming soldiers.

The level design is decent and varied. The city blocks of worker quarters and shops evoke a very "Eastern Europe in the Cold War" feeling. Ravenholm was creepy and moody, putting off a gothic horror survival vibe. I liked the ambiance of the different zones; like HL1, no two felt exactly alike.

The story is adequate, though borderline cliched. Voice acting is far better than the first game. The graphics ... well, I admit it looks cleaner and better than HL1, with much more diverse character models and smoother textures but it's still got some rough edges.

Now that I've said all that, I will say that I went through large sections of the game where I did not enjoy myself. A number of enemies (gunships, striders, snipers, certain floor turrets) do an insane amount of damage and are (in the case of the gunship and striders) ridiculously durable, taking numerous RPG rockets to knock out (the only saving grace is these enemies are usually located near an infinite RPG ammo crate). You'll have times when you are under fire and trying to do something that takes timing or precision (specifically in the stupid boat) and it just got annoying. The poison head crabs that basically make you vulnerable to being one-shotted are fast and sometimes hard to hit, and just feel like they're present to be frustrating and slow you down. All of this combined made me realize in places that I just wasn't having fun. I don't play to be frustrated. That's me, not the game, and I get other players may look at it as a challenge and enjoy it, and that's cool.

You will go through two lengthy vehicle sequences in the first half of the game--the first on an air boat, the second on a dune buggy. I did not enjoy either of these segments. Vehicle controls are clunky and awkward. You have zero protection from enemies in the vehicles and sometimes simply getting them turned the correct direction was a Herculean task. Both went on for a full segment of the game, which means you'll spend about 20% of your playtime in them. Too long. (I admit, with my second partial run, both went better.)

HL2 is stable and runs with minimal hiccups, though sometimes the game would "go dark" when I Alt-Tab'bed. I'd come back and have sound but no video, just a blank screen. That might have just been my system.

The Steam Achievements are relatively simple to get (though you might need a guide to find a few of them) and are independent of game difficulty, so if you are really having trouble with some--like fighting through Ravenholm on just the gravity gun (which is probably the hardest achievement)--dial it down to easy. I finally got it on Medium but doing so probably caused more swearing than it was worth.

In the end I still have to give this a thumbs up, because I think a lot of it is my own personal taste and I suspect others may enjoy it more than me. There is enough fun to be had, especially if you were a fan of the first one.I suspect I would have enjoyed this much more playing it when it released but having spent the last fifteen years playing more modern shooters, it just wasn't as much fun as I hoped it would be. Your mileage may vary.

Pros
- Enjoyable combat & gravity gun!
- Interesting level design

Cons
- Vehicle sequences went on far too long
- Just didn't enjoy myself for wide swaths of the game

Final Score: 6.5/10

Half-Life 2, a game that plagues my dreams.

The plot continues the story of Gordan Freeman after his escape from Black Mesa after traveling to Xen to finish what was started. The game starts out with you arriving in City 17, miraculously appearing on a train after a small talk with a figure known as the G-man. You soon learn the world you're long from knowing the depths of, has been claimed by an organisation known as the combine, an alien race that saw their moment for world domination after the earth was left weak by the catastrophe that Gordon had started and Adrian Shepard from Opposing Force had finished. As you cause problems that seem to pile faster and faster upon Gordon, you make your way across what remains of earth, traveling through the alleys of City 17, through a transportation channel that's overcome with radioactive materials, to the misty shores of "The Coast", and to a battle which is history in the making.

Half-Life 2, sitting at 14 years old now, has been critically acclaimed so many times that I couldn't even put it into a perspective, is a masterpiece that requires a detailed eye to see. The bold ideas that it shows that have squirmed their ways into just about every AAA game are something that people take for granted. The game takes narration into a new light, where instead of character blatantly saying the lore of the game, the world is alive and tells you through remnants of past years such as the burnt corpses hidden away from view in City 17, outposts with materials as if they were preparing for something, a newspapers and signs scattered across the world.

I can't describe the game in a format that would be easy to understand, just get the game for yourself and remember that art is best seen when standing far from it.

Купил в 2020 и прошел Халфу на 100% первый раз в 2020. Даже сейчас, спустя столько времени очень приятная игра, с хорошей физикой, разнообразие оружия, врагов, с хорошей музыкой. Игра стоит своей оценки на метакритике. А мне ещё осталось 2 эпизода пройти.

Fortnite Battle Royale is a free-to-play battle royale video game developed and published by Epic Games. It is a companion game to Fortnite: Save the World, a cooperative survival game with construction elements. It was initially released in early access on September 26, 2017, for Microsoft Windows, macOS, PlayStation 4, and Xbox One, followed by ports for iOS,[b] Android,[b] and Nintendo Switch the following year. Epic dropped the early access label for the game on June 29, 2020. Versions for the PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X are planned for when they launch in late 2020.

The concept of the game is similar to previous games of the genre: 100 players skydive onto an island and scavenge for gear to defend themselves from other players. Players can fight alone (Solo), with one additional player (Duos), or with a group of up to three others (Squads). As the match progresses, the playable area within the island gradually constricts, giving the players less and less room to work with. The last player or team alive wins the match. The main distinction from others in the genre is the game's construction elements, letting players build walls, obstacles, and other structures from collected resources to take cover from incoming fire or give one a strategic view advantage. Battle Royale uses a seasonal approach with battle passes to introduce new character customization content in the game, as well as limited time events, some of which correspond with changes to the game map. Since its initial release, several other game modes have been introduced, including "Battle Lab" and "Party Royale".

The idea for Battle Royale arose following the release of PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds in 2017, a similar battle royale game that was highly successful but noted for its technical flaws. Originally released as part of the early access version of Save the World, Epic later transitioned the game to a free-to-play model funded by microtransactions. Following its rise in popularity, Epic split the development team, with one focusing on Battle Royale and the other on Save the World.

Battle Royale received positive reviews from critics, who praised its learning curve, gameplay, art style, multiplayer and progression system, but noted its similarity to previous games in the genre. The game quickly rose in popularity following its release, eventually surpassing Battlegrounds in overall player count and revenue. Player count had exceeded 350 million by May 2020, while by March 2019, the game had generated over 2 billion dollars worldwide. The game has gone on to become a cultural phenomenon, with promotion through social media and several celebrities, such as Ninja, Marshmello, and Drake, contributing to the game's popularity, achieving record-high viewership on streaming platforms in the process.
